It's interesting that you have Obama as the new political headliner at a moment when Tiger Woods is the most famous athlete and one of the most famous faces in the United States, because both men are multi-racial, global children of mixed marriages
Tiger's Thai mother met his African-American father in Bangkok, and Barack's white American mother met his Kenyan father in Hawaii, so both of these men are mixed-race children.
But in America, because of the one-drop-of-blood rule, the idea that if you have any black ancestry at all that makes you black, they've tended to be categorized as black.

And yet they themselves have in interesting ways been trying to claim all of their different heritage and to say that they're not just African-American but also, in Tiger's case, Asian, part white, part Native American, and in Barack's case, part white as well.
Well, explain further about the one-drop-of-blood rule.
Do you think that's still relevant?
Well, the one-drop-of-blood rule has been a very powerful force governing race in America, you know, all the way back to slavery.
If you had any African ancestry, that made you black and thus enslavable.
And even today we live in a society that wants people to pick sides, to define themselves as either black or white.
And so, when you look at it objectively, you know, why should a Derek Jeter or a Mariah Carey or a Tiger Woods be defined as African-American, as they most commonly are.
After all, they have one parent who's white and one who's African-American.
But the strange, uncanny power of the one-drop-of-blood rule is that it does have this very powerful force in our society and in our imagination.

So do you think people like Obama and Tiger Woods, who very specifically are trying to sort of straddle that line and say yes, I identify with my black heritage but I don't want to deny my mother, too, and sort of branch out and form this new something, whatever it is, that's not either black or white but some new creation is starting to change that?
I think it's a very tricky balancing act.
I think on the one hand many Americans, you know, are tired of the simple kind of pigeon-holing of, you know, black, white, Latino, Asian-American, as if that was all that we were.
On the other hand, the forces that seek to categorize us and the pressure to define yourself as one thing or another is very powerful.
I think it's interesting.
In a way, Tiger Woods is the more revolutionary figure in all of this because he insists on calling himself Cablanasian.
Barack Obama in a way has hedged his bets.
He calls himself a black man of mixed heritage.
And I sense in a way, you know, for him to call himself simply, you know, a multi-racial man and presidential candidate would be a little bit too hard to classify for many Americans.

You know, Americans are still used to thinking in black and white, so thus he calls himself a black man as his primary identity, while also trying to acknowledge in this new way that he has a mixed family tree.
